text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single full-page diagram occupying the central field within a thick azurite frame; marginal roundels interrupt the frame at compass points. The main text is confined to Latin captions on leaves and in marginal bust labels. A vertical vine with lateral offshoots organizes eight interior roundels against an orange diaper ground, maximizing use of the central space while leaving wide borders for ancillary imagery.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata bookhand with uniform angular letterforms, precise spacing, frequent use of standard medieval abbreviations, executed by a professional scribe

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold denotes the sanctity or prominence of figures in roundels and marginal busts. Blue frames and key garments underscore hierarchical importance. Green on vine and shield leaves symbolizes growth of virtues. The orange diaper provides high contrast, while white lead applied in layers accentuates folds and pattern relief. Pigments remain vibrant, with minimal oxidation on white highlights.

features: Vertical central axis from Humilitas root to Sapientia apex
Tiered branching structure indicating order of virtues
Symmetrical lateral offshoots at lower and upper levels
Consistent circular framing for each node

decorative_elements: Green vine scroll with shield-shaped leaf terminals
Burnished gold bezants in marginal roundels
Latin captions on leaves and busts
Eight marginal busts in gold-backed roundels
White lead stenciling in diaper pattern

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill pen outlines in dark brown ink, bold contours for figural forms, delicate filigree in leaves
drawing_technique.shading_method: Light linear hatching on drapery folds, white lead highlights for volume, predominantly flat color fields
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without linear perspective; depth implied by overlapping stems and layered roundels

content_theme.scene_description: This full-page diagram is an Arbor Virtutum—an allegorical tree of virtues—set against a diapered orange ground. At the base a roundel depicts Humilitas kneeling in red robes, presenting a scroll inscribed with its name. From this root emerge three stems: two lateral stems lead to lower roundels showing Prudentia seated at a lectern (lower left) and Fortitudo as an armored figure with club (lower right), while the central stem ascends to Temperantia, who holds a bridle. From Temperantia three branches extend to a third tier: Iustitia with scales (left), Caritas embracing two children (center), and Spes leaning on an anchor (right). A final vertical stem concludes at Sapientia, depicted with an open book, at the apex. Each virtue is accompanied by five small green shield-shaped leaves bearing Latin inscriptions of related qualities. The entire schema is enclosed by a broad blue border punctuated by eight marginal busts of bearded figures—likely prophets or church fathers—set in gold-backed roundels with identifying captions. The rhythmic arrangement of roundels and leaves, together with the uniform diaper pattern, reinforces the hierarchical unity of the virtues.

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, uniformly prepared by fine scraping and pumicing; visible plummet ruling around margins; clean creamy surface with slight follicle pattern.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Excellent: pigments remain vivid; minimal flaking of minium in diaper ground at edges; slight cockling along upper margin; traces of historic reinforcement to lower margin.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf in roundels
Underdrawing visible in UV corresponding to final outlines
Regular diaper stencil work in orange and white lead
Even brush strokes in layered pigment application on robes
Consistent ruling pattern for layout and marginal captions

secondary_functions: Institutional identity as teaching tool in monastic school
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Monastic scholars or clerical students engaged in moral theology

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This Arbor Virtutum emerges from a thirteenth-century Western European monastic context, reflecting the scholastic impulse to map ethical concepts into visual schemas. Executed in a professional Parisian workshop, the diagram integrates the four cardinal and three theological virtues, rooted in Humilitas, into a coherent hierarchical structure. The use of gold leaf and a vivid palette aligns with contemporary advancements in manuscript illumination, while the diaper ground resonates with luxury Psalter decoration. The eight interior roundels and surrounding prophets bridge symbolic theology and visual didacticism, guiding the viewer’s meditation from humble foundation to divine wisdom. Script and pigment application exhibit hallmarks of the high Gothic period: precise textura quadrata, layered white lead highlights, and underdrawing that informs finely controlled contour lines. Iconographically, the virtues’ attributes—scales for Iustitia, anchor for Spes—adhere closely to patristic descriptions while the presence of Humilitas at the root underscores its primacy in medieval moral thought. Comparatively, the diagram shares compositional affinities with the Moralized Bible of Oxford and the Speculum Humanae Salvationis but innovates by centralizing Humility rather than Christ, signaling a subtle shift toward personal ethical cultivation. As both art object and pedagogical tool, the manuscript negotiates the boundary between devotional luxury and intellectual utility, embodying the dual priorities of monastic education and aesthetic refinement.
